affiliations.name: Assistant professor in the Sociology Department at George Washington University and a member of the National Consortium on Violence Research (NCOVR). Her research examines the intersection of neighborhoods, race, and crime. A new line of research assesses the relationships among music, culture, and social identity, particularly as they apply to hip hop and minority youth in disadvantaged communities

Assistant professor in the Department of Criminology and Criminal Justice at the University of Missouri‐St. Louis and a member of the National Consortium on Violence Research (NCOVR). He is also a W.E.B. DuBois Fellow with the National Institute of Justice. His research interests include crime over the life course; neighborhood, school, and family processes on adolescent development; and testing criminological theories

open_access_categories.name: Closed

Dimensions.title: PREDICTING WHO REOFFENDS: THE NEGLECTED ROLE OF NEIGHBORHOOD CONTEXT IN RECIDIVISM STUDIES

Semantic Scholar.abstract: Prior studies of recidivism have focused almost exclusively on individual-level characteristics of offenders and their offenses to explore the correlates of reoffending. Notably absent from these studies are measures reflecting the neighborhood contexts in which individuals live. The current research addresses this shortcoming. Using data on a sample of ex-offenders in Multnomah County, Oregon (Portland and surrounding area) in conjunction with 2000 census data, we answer two questions. First, which individual-level factors influence rates of recidivism? Second, to what extent does neighborhood socioeconomic status account for variation in the reoffending behavior of ex-prisoners that is not explained by their individual-level characteristics? We find that those who return to disadvantaged neighborhoods recidivate at a greater rate while those who return to resource rich or affluent communities recidivate at a lesser rate, controlling for individual-level factors.

Semantic Scholar.title: Predicting Who Reoffends: The Neglected Role of Neighborhood Context in Recidivism Studies

Unpaywall.title: PREDICTING WHO REOFFENDS: THE NEGLECTED ROLE OF NEIGHBORHOOD CONTEXT IN RECIDIVISM STUDIES*

records.abstract: Prior studies of recidivism have focused almost exclusively on individual-level characteristics of offenders and their offenses to explore the correlates of reoffending. Notably absent from these studies are measures reflecting the neighborhood contexts in which individuals live. The current research addresses this shortcoming. Using data on a sample of ex-offenders in Multnomah County, Oregon (Portland and surrounding area) in conjunction with 2000 census data, we answer two questions. We find that those who return to disadvantaged neighborhoods recidivate at a greater rate while those who return to resource rich or affluent communities recidivate at a lesser rate, controlling for individual-level factors.
